metadata.title: So that’s what Apache does!. The simplest application of Apache2 I… | by Rakshit Raj | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Get started with the Apache server. Learn to host and share files using the Apache server on Ubuntu. Learn to install and use apache2 with code examples.

all_paragraphs: In November 2019, I attended a workshop on ‘Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning’. Unlike others, this was an advanced workshop on the mathematics behind the algorithms that make up Machine Learning. As an undergrad, I am not surprised that most of the math had gone over my head.
I am thankful that the workshop for introducing me to advanced mathematical concepts that I am yet to learn, but it wasn’t until the hands-on session when I found something I could comprehend.

My introduction to Apache was purely by chance. During the hands-on session, our RC wanted to share his Jupyter notebooks with us. Since no one had access to the college’s cloud and all other means of data transfer were not nearly sexy enough for sharing with everybody, he asked if anyone was using Linux. I was.

It was an Apache server to the rescue. We hosted the files on an Apache server running on my computer so that everyone could access them. That is what I learned in that workshop, and I shall show you how to do something similar here.

Apache is the most commonly used Web server on Linux systems. Web servers are used to serve Web pages requested by client computers. Clients typically request and view Web pages using Web browser applications such as Firefox, Opera, Chromium, or Internet Explorer.
In this article, we shall host a folder containing an HTML file using the Apache server. I will show how to do this on an ubuntu machine.
We begin by installing Apache2 on our system.
Installing apache2 creates an executable in /etc/init.d/apache2. I can manage the server by invoking this file.
Invoking the file without arguments is also useful as it churns out the Usage message that informs us about the various options available.
Running the apache2 server loads the index.html page in var/www/html/ folder by default. To do this, just start the server and enter your IP address in any browser.
After installing the Apache2 server should run by default. Check this using:
If the server is running, you will see a message like this.
If the server is off, as it was on my system as I show this, you will see a difference in the Active: message.
Start the apache2 server using the start command.
Instead of using the executable at /etc/init.d/apache2 you can also use the systemctl command.

This will display your IP address. In case you are running networking services, you will see more than one output value as shown below. In such a case, I prefer to use the IPv4 address and the first value of IP.
You will see the Apache2 Ubuntu Default Page. This means that the Apache server is active and running.

Now that we have tested that Apache server works, let’s copy the files we want to host to suitable locations. In our example, we want to host a folder named folder containing a file named index.html. I have placed this folder on our home directory.
We have to use sudo since root owns /var and users apart from root do not have write permissions to the / directory.
To host the files located inside /var/www/html/ we need to change their ownership. Since we copied folder using sudo, the files belong to the user root of the group root.
I will change the ownership and group of /var/www/html/ folder to www-data
You can view the changes using
Whenever I change the files being hosted or the properties of the server, I will need to restart the apache server (if it was running already).

Open up a browser and go to your hosted file, i.e. the folder called folder. Since folder contains an index.html we will see a webpage being loaded. Well, almost loaded since we didn't include any of the style sheets and resources that go with it.
Had you placed a .zip file inside folder, you could have easily downloaded it. That's what I did at the workshop.

To find out more about apache2, you could read the man pages on your system.
I recommend checking out the official page of the Apache HTTPD Server Project. For more help regarding servers on Ubuntu, check out Canonical’s Ubuntu Server Guide.
Check out more of my work on my Github profile.
I recommend trying out the code yourself. Implementing the Apache server mentioned in this article will take less time than it took for you to read it!
